headline: Berkshire Hathaway Slashes Stake in Amazon by More Than 75%
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway slashed its stake in Amazon by more than 75% in the fourth quarter, while also building a stake in the New York Times, his last new bet as chief executive officer of the conglomerate. Bloomberg's Abeer Abu Omar reports.

content.summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway slashed its stake in Amazon by more than 75% in the fourth quarter, while also building a stake in the New York Times, his last new bet as chief executive officer of the conglomerate. Bloomberg's Abeer Abu Omar reports.

headline: New York Times Stock Rallies on Berkshire Hathaway Stake-Building
summary: Shares in the New York Times rose after Berkshire Hathaway said it added a position in the media company and sold shares in Bank of America, Apple and Amazon.  Berkshire bought 5.1 million shares of the New York Times during the December quarter, Warren Buffett’s last few months as chief executive.  It sold stock in Apple, marking the third-straight period it cut its stake in the iPhone maker.

It sold stock in Apple, marking the third-straight period it cut its stake in the iPhone maker.

headline: UBS lifts forecast for big tech bond sales this year
summary: UBS lifted its 2026 forecasts for U.S. tech investment grade bond sales on Wednesday, pointing to rising spending by ‌big tech firms, while cutting its forecast for leveraged loans on expectations that ‌AI-related disruption could curb supply. Several megacap tech companies including Meta, Amazon and Alphabet have announced big increases to their ​capital expenditure plans during the latest earnings season. After years of outsized gains, big tech stocks, meanwhile, have fallen in 2026, as investors question whether heavy AI spending will generate sufficient returns to warrant lofty valuations.

content.title: UBS lifts forecast for big tech bond sales this year
content.summary: UBS lifted its 2026 forecasts for U.S. tech investment grade bond sales on Wednesday, pointing to rising spending by ‌big tech firms, while cutting its forecast for leveraged loans on expectations that ‌AI-related disruption could curb supply. Several megacap tech companies including Meta, Amazon and Alphabet have announced big increases to their ​capital expenditure plans during the latest earnings season. After years of outsized gains, big tech stocks, meanwhile, have fallen in 2026, as investors question whether heavy AI spending will generate sufficient returns to warrant lofty valuations.

thumbnail.caption: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen in Zurich

headline: The Race to Build Data Centers Is Driving an 'AI Debt Boom'
summary: The data-center construction frenzy is upending expectations for U.S. corporate borrowing.  If Amazon, Meta and Google follow through on their planned investment, total spending by so-called "hyperscalers" could hit $770 billion this year, UBS said—23% higher than its previous forecast.  The bank said U.S. tech companies would continue to borrow globally, after Alphabet's recent $31.5 billion deal, which included bonds in Swiss francs and British pounds.

content.title: The Race to Build Data Centers Is Driving an 'AI Debt Boom'
content.summary: The data-center construction frenzy is upending expectations for U.S. corporate borrowing.  If Amazon, Meta and Google follow through on their planned investment, total spending by so-called "hyperscalers" could hit $770 billion this year, UBS said—23% higher than its previous forecast.  The bank said U.S. tech companies would continue to borrow globally, after Alphabet's recent $31.5 billion deal, which included bonds in Swiss francs and British pounds.

headline: Wall Street Hunts for Bottom as S&P Retests ‘Rock Solid’ Support

While the S&P 500 once again held the line on Tuesday, closing up 0.1% at 6,843.22, it earlier fell to intraday low of 6,775.50.

headline: UPS Labor Clash And Closures Test Cost Cuts And Network Resilience
summary: UPS (NYSE:UPS) is facing a legal challenge from the Teamsters over its new Driver Choice Program, with the union seeking a preliminary injunction. The Teamsters allege the program violates the national master agreement, weakens union rights, and involves direct dealing with drivers. UPS has also announced plans to close 22 union staffed facilities across 18 states and cut up to 30,000 positions tied to reduced Amazon related business. For a company as central to global parcel and freight...

headline: Did Warren Buffett Give Up on Amazon? He Sold 77% Before Leaving

This position expanded over time — particularly after Amazon’s 20:1 stock split in 2022 — reaching 10 million shares worth approximately $2.1 billion by the end of last year’s third quarter. headline: Saving What's Left At The End Of The Month Sounds Sensible. It Might Be Secretly Sabotaging Your Financial Future, Along With These Habits
summary: Saving whatever is left at the end of the month sounds responsible. It feels disciplined. It feels practical. But as one Reddit user recently put it, for most people, “nothing is left.” That simple observation sparked a massive discussion in the r/povertyfinance community about everyday money habits that feel normal, but quietly drain wealth over time. The consensus was that if you wait to save until after everyone else gets paid, you usually end up paying yourself last. Pay Yourself First, Not

headline: Fed minutes, Warren Buffett's Amazon stake, oil prices rise
summary: Yahoo Finance Senior Producer John Hyland tracks Wednesday's top moving stocks and biggest market stories in this Market Minute. Oil (CL=F, BZ=F) prices are jumping as tensions continue brewing between the US and Iran. Former Berkshire Hathaway (BRK-B, BRK-A) CEO Warren Buffett sold 75% of his Amazon (AMZN) stake in his final quarter. The Federal Reserve will release its January meeting minutes at 2:00 p.m. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

The Federal Reserve will release its January meeting minutes at 2:00 p.m.

Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: Berkshire Cuts Amazon Stake, Makes Bet on New York Times
summary: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. slashed its holding in Amazon.com Inc. by more than 75% in the fourth quarter, while also building a stake in the New York Times Co.   Warren Buffett's last new bet as chief executive officer.  The conglomerate acquired 5.1 million shares of the media publishing company in the three months through December, a stake worth $351.7 million at year-end, according to a regulatory filing Tuesday. Bloomberg's Matthew Palazola joins to discuss.

content.title: Berkshire Cuts Amazon Stake, Makes Bet on New York Times
content.description:
Berkshire Hathaway Inc. slashed its holding in Amazon.com Inc. by more than 75% in the fourth quarter, while also building a stake in the New York Times Co.   Warren Buffett's last new bet as chief executive officer. 
The conglomerate acquired 5.1 million shares of the media publishing company in the three months through December, a stake worth $351.7 million at year-end, according to a regulatory filing Tuesday. Bloomberg's Matthew Palazola joins to discuss.
content.summary: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. slashed its holding in Amazon.com Inc. by more than 75% in the fourth quarter, while also building a stake in the New York Times Co.   Warren Buffett's last new bet as chief executive officer.  The conglomerate acquired 5.1 million shares of the media publishing company in the three months through December, a stake worth $351.7 million at year-end, according to a regulatory filing Tuesday. Bloomberg's Matthew Palazola joins to discuss.

headline: Buffett Goes Out Like a Bear With $5 Billion in 4Q Sales
summary: Warren Buffett's last quarter as Berkshire Hathaway's CEO reflected a bearish sentiment as he prepares to depart the firm, handing the reins to Greg Abel. The conglomerate cut its Amazon stake by 75%, with the position likely gaining 130-140% and performing broadly in line with the S&P 500. Chevron and Chubb, among its top 10 holdings, saw position increases. Berkshire Hathaway is also building a stake in the New York Times Co. Bloomberg Intelligence Senior Property & Casualty Insurance Matthew Palazola joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss. He speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

content.title: Buffett Goes Out Like a Bear With $5 Billion in 4Q Sales
content.description: Warren Buffett's last quarter as Berkshire Hathaway's CEO reflected a bearish sentiment as he prepares to depart the firm, handing the reins to Greg Abel. The conglomerate cut its Amazon stake by 75%, with the position likely gaining 130-140% and performing broadly in line with the S&P 500. Chevron and Chubb, among its top 10 holdings, saw position increases. Berkshire Hathaway is also building a stake in the New York Times Co. Bloomberg Intelligence Senior Property & Casualty Insurance Matthew Palazola joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss. He speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.
